sen.j: 袱紗（ふくさ）とは贈り物の金品などを包んだり、覆うのに使用する方形の布である。
sen.e: A fukusa is a square piece of cloth to wrap or cover a gift of money.

sen.j: 袱紗は元々は貴重品などが収蔵された箱上に掛けられていた風呂敷である。
sen.e: A fukusa is originally a furoshiki (wrapping cloth) to cover a box in which precious things are stored.
A fukusa is originally a furoshiki (wrapping cloth) to cover a box in which precious things are stored.

sen.j: その風呂敷が贈答品を運ぶ時の汚れや日焼け防止として用いられるようになり1枚の布地から裏地付きの絹製で四方に亀房と呼ばれる房付きのものに変わった。
sen.e: This furoshiki came to be used to prevent gifts from becoming dirty during transportation or faded by sun and changed from a single cloth to be a lined cloth with tassels called kamebusa (a turtle-shaped knot).

This furoshiki came to be used to prevent gifts from becoming dirty during transportation or faded by sun and changed from a single cloth to be a lined silk cloth with tassels called kamebusa (a turtle-shaped knot).
sen.cmt: ”絹製”という部分を挿入しました。
sen.e: This furoshiki came to be used to prevent gifts from becoming dirty during transportation or faded by sun and changed from a single cloth to be a lined silk cloth with tassels called kamebusa (a turtle-shaped knot).

sen.j: 慶弔行事の金品を贈る時の儀礼や心使いとして広蓋（黒塗りの盆）と併せて用いられるようになった。
sen.e: It came to be used with a black-lacquered tray by courtesy and to show care to send monetary gifts for events of congratulations and condolences.

sen.e: It came to be used with hirobuta (a black-lacquered tray) by courtesy and to show care to send monetary gifts for events of congratulations and condolences.

sen.j: 熨斗袋の水引がくずれたり袋が皺になることを防ぐ事や先方の心中や祭礼を重んじ、喜びや悲しみを共にする気持ちを表している。
sen.e: A fukusa prevents damage to mizuhiki (decorative Japanese cord made from twisted paper) of a noshi envelope or prevents the envelope from wrinkling, and shows respect for the receiver's feeling and ritual events as well as empathy to share joy and sadness.

sen.e: It is also said to be a form of sensitive caring to enclose the gift with a noshi envelope and wrap it with fukusa.

sen.e: In general a fukusa is a piece of square cloth of crepe or silk smaller than a furoshiki and used to wrap smaller things than a furoshiki.

Only a fukusa which is purple is used for gifts for both congratulations and condolences.
